bibl.title: Martin J. McDonough v. Territory of Washington. Petition for Writ of Habeas Corpus
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

org.orgName: District Court of Washington Territory and the Third Judicial District

body.p: In the District Court of Washington Territory and for the Third Judicial District therof, holding terms at Seattle, for the counties of King and Kitsap Territory of Washington - Plaintiff } vs. M.J. McDonough L. - Defendant.
In the matter of the application } Petition for of M.J. McDonough for a Writ of Habeas Corpus Writ of Habeas Corpus.
In the Hon. Judge of the above entitled court. the petition of M.J. McDonough respectfully shows
1st

That M.J. McDonough is unlawfully imprisoned, detained, confined and restrained of his liberty by John H. McGraw. Sheriff of King County, Washington Territory, at the County Jail in said County and Territory in the City of Seattle.
2nd

That the cause or pretense of each imprisonment detention, confinment and restraint, according to the best of the knowledge or belief of your petitioner is that your petitioner has been adjudged, by one G.A. Hill, Justice of the Peace, in and for Seattle Precinct, King County, Washington Territory, to be guilty of an alleged crime, to wit, contempt of court, and that after having him so adjudged guilty, as aforesaid, he was sentenced by said Justice of the Peace to pay a fine of five dollars and $17.60 cents

and that he stand committed until the same be paid, and before any process was issued out of the Court of said Justice of the Peace to collect said fine, and costs or any demand made on your petitioner to pay the same your petitioner was unlawfully arrested, committed, deatained, confined and restrained of his liberty by virtue of an unlawful and illegal and commitment issued by said Justice which commanded that your petitioner be so imprisoned and restrained of his liberty until such fine and costs be paid and that your petitioner be allowed $2.50 per day imprisonment
3rd
That said imprisonment, detention, confinement and restraint an illegal and that the illegality thereof consists in this - to wit
1st That your petitioner is not guily of the offense for which he was illegally tried, convicted, sentenced and committed, as aforesaid.

2nd That your petitoner is illegally and unlawfully imprisoned and restrained of his liberty, and in this to wit, he has been confined and committed by said Justice, as aforesaid, in of the punishment provided in statements.

3rd That the punishment presented for said alleged offense of which your petitoner was so adjudged to be guilty, to wit, resistance to the lawful order or process issued by said Justice of the Peace and which is alleged to have constituted the contempt of Court complained of and as your petitoner believes

is, by section 1843 of the code of Washington-Territory as follows "Punishment for contempt may be by fine, not exceeding twenty-five dollars, or by imprisonment in the County Jail not exceeding two days, at the discretion of the Justice". The jurisdiction given to the Justiec of the Peace is carefully limited, at his discretion he may either fine or imprison but no authority is given him to do both.

The form of the Judgement Entry to be made in the docket of each Justice, as prescribed by section 1847 of said Code, is as follows "is convicted of the contempt aforesaid and is adjudged by the under signed to pay a fine of _____ dollars. The date and signature of the Justice following. The form goes no further and makes no provision for the commitment and imprisonment of the defendant. Excepting that should the Justice use the discretion allowed him and imprison instead of fine, the said form says in brackets ("or be imprisoned etc.")

How the punishment for said offense shall be inflicted by said Justice is strictly laid down and predefined by Section 1848 of said Code- as follows. "If any person convicted of a contempt be adjudged to be imprisoned, a warrant of commitment shall be issued by the Justice "but" If he be adjudged to pay a fine a process may be issued to collect the same" And no former or authority, either express or implied, is given

said Justice to imprison until said fine and costs of the proceeding are paid. Your petitoner is illegally imprisoned, detained, confined and restained of his liberty because the said Justice exceeded his jurisdiction and the authority given him by statute in sentencing him to pay a fine and at the same time sentencing him to imprisonment until the same he paid.

4th That your petitoner has fees and is now illegaly committed and is now illegaly imprisoned and restrained of his liberty because the commitment issued by said Justice as aforesaid upon which the said Sheriff holds imprisons, confines and restrains of his liberty your petitoner, was unlawfully and illegaly issued, and said commitment was and is unlawful, illegal and void.
5th Because your petitoner is deprived of his liberty without due process of law.
6th Because your petitioner has never been lawfully informed of the notion and cause of the accusation against him

7th Because the said Justice of the Peace in so committing and causing to be imprisoned and restrained of his libery, your petitoner as did without having authority in the premises to commit as aforesaid
8th Because the said imprisonment is for for eleven days and time limited by the statute in each case made and provided only for only allows an imprisonment for two days
9th Because he is imprisoned and sentenced to hard labor and said Justice has no jurisdiction to so imprisonment and sentence him
10th Because said imprisonment is for an indefinite time. There being no time but in the said order of commitment from which the said time of eleven days shall commence to

11th Because the said petitioner was so committed and imprisoned before any return was made by the of said court on the hereby issued by said court for the collection go said fine and costs as to whether or no the said dine was or was not, or cruled or could be collected
